'''''Inocybe lacera''''' ([[common name|commonly known]] as the '''torn fibrecap''') is a [[mushroom poisoning|poisonous]] species of [[mushroom]] in the genus ''[[Inocybe]]''. Its appearance is that of a typical "[[little brown mushroom]]": small, brown and indistinct. However, it is distinguishable by its microscopic features, particularly its long, smooth [[spore]]s. As with many other species of ''Inocybe'', ''I. lacera'' contains the poisonous chemical [[muscarine]] which, if consumed, can lead to [[salivation]], [[lacrimation]], [[urination]], [[defecation]], [[gastrointestinal problem]]s and [[emesis]]. Found in Europe and North America, it typically grows in autumn in [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed woods]], favouring sandy soil. There are several documented [[subspecies]] in addition to the main ''I. lacera'' var ''lacera'', including the dwarf form ''I. lacera'' var. ''subsquarrosa'' and ''I. lacera'' var. ''heterosperma'', found in North America.

==Taxonomy==
''Inocybe lacera'' was first described by Swedish [[Mycology|mycologist]] [[Elias Magnus Fries]], but was placed into the genus ''Inocybe'' by [[Paul Kummer]]<ref name="Phillips"/> in his 1871 work, ''Der Führer in die Pilzkunde''.<ref name="Kuo"/> As several forms of the species are recognised, the main variety is sometimes known as ''Inocybe lacera'' var. ''lacera''.<ref name="Jordan">{{cite book |title= The Encyclopedia of Fungi of Britain and Europe|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ULhwByKCyEwC&pg=PA292&dq=%22Inocybe+lacera%22&lr=lang_en&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES&client=firefox-a|accessdate= 2008-07-31|last= Jordan|first= Michael|year= 2004|publisher= [[Frances Lincoln]]|location= London|isbn= 978-0-7112-2378-3|page= 292}}</ref> It is [[common name|commonly known]] as the Torn Fibrecap,<ref name="Sterry"/> while in German it is known as ''Gemeiner Wirrkopf'' and in French as ''Inocybe déchiré''.<ref name="RogersMushrooms">{{cite web |url= http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~6444.asp|title= Inocybe lacera|accessdate=2009-02-15 |last= Phillips|first= Roger|publisher=RogersMushrooms}}</ref>

==Description==
[[File:Inocybe.lacera2.-.lindsey.jpg|thumb|left|''I. lacera'' gills.]]
In appearance, ''I. lacera'' is a typical "[[little brown mushroom]]",<ref name="Kuo">{{cite web |url= http://www.mushroomexpert.com/inocybe_lacera.html|title= Inocybe lacera|accessdate=2009-02-15 |last= Kuo|first= Michael|date=February 2005|publisher= MushroomExpert.com}}</ref> but specific features are very variable.<ref name="Sterry"/> It typically features a convex [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] measuring {{convert|1|to|3|cm|in|1}} across, with a small umbo.<ref name="Phillips"/> The margin of the cap curves inwards, and often splits.<ref name="Sterry"/> In colour, it is [[Snuff (tobacco)|snuff]]-brown, and in consistency, it is [[fibrils|fibrillose]]<ref name="Phillips"/> and scaley.<ref name="Sterry"/> The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe, or stem]], is {{convert|2|to|3|cm|in|1}} tall, and {{convert|3|to|6|mm|in}} thick, brown at the slightly bulbous base, but lighter towards the apex, and, again, fibrillose.<ref name="Phillips"/> The stem lacks a ring.<ref name="Jordan"/> The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is white. The [[lamella (mycology)|adnexed gills]] are white in younger specimens, soon changing to a clay-buff with white edges.<ref name="Phillips">{{cite book |title= Mushrooms and Other Fungi of Great Britain and Europe|last= Phillips|first= Roger|year= 1981|publisher= [[Pan Books]]|location= London|isbn= 0-330-26441-9|pages=152–153}}</ref>

===Microscopic features===
''Inocybe lacera'' has thick-walled, [[wikt:fusiform|fusiform]] [[cystidia]], which have [[Apical membrane#Membrane polarity|apical]] encrustations. It has a brown [[spore print]], while the subcylindrical [[spore]]s are smooth, typically measuring 11 to 15 by 4.5 to 6 [[micrometer|µm]] in size.<ref name="Phillips"/> ''I. lacera'' is one of a small group of related species with particularly long, cylindrical spores, the others of which can typically be found on [[sand dunes]].<ref name="Pegler">{{cite book |title= Mushrooms and Toadstools|last= Pegler|first= David N.|year= 1983|publisher= Mitchell Beazley Publishing|location= London|isbn= 0-85533-500-9|page= 57}}</ref> The spore shape is more typical of species from the order [[Boletales]].<ref name="Kuo"/> These features make the ''I. lacera'' easily recognisable microscopically.<ref name="Phillips"/> The "dwarf form", ''I. lacera'' var. ''subsquarrosa'', has small spores and thin-walled cystidia, while a North American variant, ''I. lacera'' var. ''heterosperma'' has spores varying from 5.5 to 15.5 µm in length.<ref name="Kuo"/> The species has 4-spored [[basidia]].<ref name="Jordan"/>

===Similar species===
''[[Inocybe hystrix]]'' is similar in appearance, but noticeably more scaly. It is also far less common.<ref name="Sterry"/>

==Edibility==
''Inocybe lacera'' has mild-tasting flesh and a mild, mealy smell.<ref name="Phillips"/><ref name="Kuo"/> The North American variety ''I. lacera'' var. ''heterosperma'' has a [[wikt:spermatic|spermatic]] smell.<ref name="Kuo"/> However, species of ''[[Inocybe]]'' should always be avoided when choosing mushrooms for consumption, as many of the members of the genus are dangerously toxic.<ref name="Kuo"/> ''I. lacera'' is known to be poisonous,<ref name="Pegler"/> containing quantities of the toxic compound [[muscarine]]. Consumption of the mushroom typically leads to [[salivation]], [[lacrimation]], [[urination]], [[defecation]], [[gastrointestinal problem]]s and [[emesis]] (vomiting), which has given rise to the acronym SLUDGE.<ref name="Hall">{{cite book |title= Edible and Poisonous Mushrooms of the World|last= Hall|first= Ian Robert|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=yqHA_M7BVRcC&pg=PA109&dq=%22Inocybe+lacera%22&lr=lang_en&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES&client=firefox-a#PPA108,M1|accessdate= 2008-08-19|author2= Buchanan, Peter K.|author3= Stephenson, Steven L.|author4= Yun, Wang|author5= Cole, Anthony L. J.|year= 2003|publisher= [[Timber Press]]|isbn= 978-0-88192-586-9|pages= 108–109}}</ref> Other potential effects include a drop in [[blood pressure]], [[sweating]] and death due [[respiratory failure]].<ref name="Hall"/>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Inocybe lacera'' can be found throughout autumn on sandy soil, especially with pine,<ref name="Phillips"/> though it is typically found in mixed woods.<ref name="Pegler"/> It grows [[mycorrhizal]]ly with both conifers and hardwoods, and the fruiting bodies can be found alone, in scattered groups, or growing gregariously.<ref name="Kuo"/> It is most commonly found on the edge of pathways through woodland,<ref name="Pegler"/> and another common habitat is on old, moss-covered fire sites.<ref name="Jordan"/> Other habitats include [[heathland]] and [[Sand dunes#Coastal dunes|coastal dunes]].<ref name="Sterry">{{cite book |title= Complete Guide to British Mushrooms & Toadstools|author1=Sterry, Paul |author2=Hughes, Barry |year= 2009|publisher= [[HarperCollins]]|isbn= 978-0-00-723224-6|page= 196}}</ref> It can be found in [[Europe]]<ref name="Phillips"/> and [[North America]].<ref name="Kuo"/> In some areas of [[Montana]], it can be found growing in the spring, under ''[[Populus tremuloides]]''.<ref name="Kuo"/>
